concern: I'm in a MA program right now and we just started in-person learning. Until this week, I had been at my parents' house doing online school from there. While I'm definitely not the biggest proponent of online school, I was actually really enjoying life at home. I got to focus on doing readings and work without worrying about maintaining my own living space, I didn't have a commute to and from classes, and I really enjoyed hanging out with my family every day. Now I'm in a different city which is still pretty shut down from the pandemic, living alone, I can't see anyone, I haven't been able to focus on my coursework that much, and I just feel really *lonely* especially since the people in my cohort aren't keen on getting together due to the pandemic. Even though I absolutely love my program and what I'm studying, I'm starting to question if it's worth the lifestyle choices that are necessary (e.g., moving away from home, the job search being global rather than local). Now, I'm finding myself wishing the weeks would pass until I can go back during the break. I'm wondering if anyone else feels the same way and how they cope with it. I'm also wondering if moving away for grad school is that much better if there weren't a pandemic shutting everything down/limiting any social activities; especially since so many people refer to grad school as an isolating experience anyway.

dialogue_total.statement: Hello! I'm glad you're here today. Feel free to share anything that's on your mind or any concerns you might have.

client: Hey, thanks for seeing me. I've just been feeling really out of place since I moved for grad school. It's like this big mix of loneliness and questioning if this whole experience is even worth it.

That sounds really tough, adjusting to a new place and facing such big questions. What are some things that you've noticed about your life here that have been challenging or different from what you expected?

client: Well, for starters, I really miss the comfort and support of being around my family. Plus, living alone and not having any in-person interactions has been way harder than I thought, especially with everything still being so restricted.

It sounds like missing your family and facing isolation have been really significant for you. What are some things that you hope to achieve while you're in grad school, and how does that align with what you're experiencing now?

Honestly, I hope to gain a deep understanding of my field and build a solid foundation for my future career. But with everything feeling so isolating right now, it's difficult to see how I'm making any meaningful progress towards those goals.

It seems like there's a big gap between your goals and what you're experiencing right now. What might it look like if things were different, and you felt more connected or supported while working towards your career goals?

I think if things were different, I'd be more engaged with my coursework and maybe even have a study group or something. I'd feel more supported if there was more sense of community or if I had people to talk to regularly who are going through the same experiences.

It sounds like creating a sense of community and connection is really important for you. Based on what you said, possible options could include joining a virtual study group or finding online forums where students share their experiences. What do you think would be some first steps towards feeling more connected and supported?

Finding a virtual study group seems like a good start, so I might try reaching out to classmates online to see if anyone's interested. Also, I could look for online communities or forums related to my field to connect with others who are going through similar experiences.

You've got some solid steps lined up, like finding a virtual study group and exploring online communities to feel more connected. It's clear how important it is for you to create a supportive network around your studies. Taking these actions could help bridge that gap between feeling isolated and achieving your goals. Remember, reaching out is a strong move and I admire your willingness to do so. Let's plan on touching base next time to see how these steps are going and explore new ways to enhance your sense of community. You're definitely on the right path, and I believe in your ability to make that meaningful progress.
Thanks, I appreciate the support. I'll start looking into those options and hopefully find some people to connect with. I'll let you know how it goes next time we meet.

concern: I have never been in an academic setting that challenged me so much. In undergrad I was always on top of my work and had enough time to enjoy myself, go to the gym, and even party. In my second year of my PhD program all I do is work and on the weekends I usually sleep or go out somewhere just to try to enjoy myself. Now that the semester has begun I lost my Sundays to a full day of class work. I am so lucky to do what I love, but I love it a lot less when I am being overworked. It does not help that my PI is an absolute workaholic. How do people not burn out working 6 days a week with such mentally involved tasks?

dialogue_total.statement: Hello! It's great to have you here. Is there anything on your mind that you'd like to talk about today?
Hey, thanks for having me. Yeah, I've just been feeling super overwhelmed with my workload lately and it's starting to get to me.
That sounds really challenging. You feel overwhelmed because your workload is weighing heavily on you. What's been going on with your workload recently?
client: Well, ever since the semester started, it's like my schedule has been completely taken over by work. It's just nonstop, and I find myself struggling to keep up.
therapist: It sounds like your schedule has been really demanding since the semester began. How do you feel this impact on your workload is affecting other areas of your life?
client: Honestly, it's affecting everything. I barely have time to relax or do things I enjoy, and it's starting to take a toll on my mood and energy levels.

It sounds like the overwhelming workload is not only impacting your schedule but also your overall well-being. How do you envision your life might be different if you had more balance and time for yourself?
I think if I had more balance and time for myself, I’d feel a lot more at ease. I miss having energy to do things outside of work, like hitting the gym or just chilling with friends.

It sounds like having more balance and energy is important to you, and you'd like to have time for activities you enjoy. Based on what you've mentioned, possible options could include setting specific times for relaxation or engaging in activities like going to the gym or spending time with friends. What are some steps you think you could take to create this balance?

I'm trying to figure out where I can cut back without falling behind. Maybe setting stricter boundaries with my work hours could help. I’m also thinking about scheduling in gym time like it's a class I can't miss.

Setting stricter boundaries with work hours and treating gym time as a non-negotiable part of your schedule sound like great steps toward achieving balance. How do you feel about creating a specific action plan to implement these changes, and what might be some challenges you could anticipate along the way?

I feel a bit hopeful about creating an action plan, but I'm also worried about sticking to it with the pressure from my workload. The biggest challenge might be prioritizing these changes when it feels like there's always something urgent to do for school.

It's understandable to feel hopeful yet concerned about sticking to a plan with pressing school demands. Prioritizing can indeed be challenging. To support these changes, possible options include setting small, manageable goals or having a weekly check-in with yourself to monitor progress. What are your thoughts on these options, and are there other strategies you might consider for overcoming these barriers?

I think setting small goals could definitely help me feel less overwhelmed. A weekly check-in sounds useful too, kind of like a reality check to see if I’m staying on track. Maybe I could also try talking to my PI about managing expectations a bit better.

You've shared some really insightful steps toward finding that balance you’re aiming for. Setting small goals and having those weekly check-ins, like a reality check, sound like excellent ways to stay grounded and focused. Discussing expectations with your PI could also offer clarity and support. It’s wonderful to see you approaching this with such thoughtfulness and openness.

Remember, it’s okay to adjust your plans as needed—flexibility can be a strength. I’m here to support you every step of the way. Perhaps starting with one specific action this week, like scheduling that gym time or having a conversation with your PI, might make the process feel more manageable. I look forward to hearing about your progress and am here whenever you need to discuss things further. Keep up the great work, and take care!
Thanks, I really appreciate the support and suggestions. I'll give it a shot this week and see how it goes.

{"reasoning":"The client has identified specific steps, like setting boundaries and scheduling gym time, and discussed potential challenges. A plan was suggested with flexibility, and the client is ready to try these strategies. Termination goals have been met.","determination":"move"}

concern:
Will be having my Master's Thesis proposal defense in the morning, and I'm all a bit tense and anxious and nervous and all the things that have going through my head. 

Been sleepy all day as if this is a way for me to cope with the stress it causes. Wish me luck everyone, good luck also to the countless graduate students who will be defending their own works!


Update: 

I cant believe it's done! I passed the proposal defence. Now I cant rest for a week from .

dialogue_total.statement: Hi there! I'm glad you're here. Please feel free to share what's on your mind or anything you'd like to discuss today.

Hey, thanks for meeting with me. I just wanted to chat about how I felt leading up to and after my Master's Thesis proposal defense. It was such a whirlwind of emotions, and even though I passed, I still feel a bit of that stress lingering.

It sounds like your Master's Thesis proposal defense was quite an emotional experience for you. You feel a mix of relief for having passed, but also some lingering stress from the whole process. Can you share more about what aspects of the experience stood out to you?

client: Yeah, it was just such an intense buildup, you know? The anticipation and the fear of messing up were overwhelming. Even though it turned out okay, I think my brain is still processing all of that pressure.
It seems like the anticipation and fear really took a toll on you, even though the outcome was positive. What do you think would change for you if that lingering stress eased up?
Honestly, I think I'd feel a lot lighter and more relaxed. I could probably focus better on what's next and enjoy the break I have without that constant tension hanging around.

It sounds like feeling lighter and more relaxed would really allow you to enjoy your break and focus on future tasks without that tension. What are some things that have helped you unwind or relax in the past?

Well, sometimes just taking some time to myself, maybe going for a walk or listening to music, can help me unwind. I also find that hanging out with friends or doing something creative, like drawing, can be pretty soothing.

It sounds like spending time alone, going for walks, listening to music, and engaging in creative activities have been helpful for you in the past. Based on what you shared, possible options for easing this lingering stress could include setting aside regular time for these activities or trying something new like a creative project. What would you like to focus on to help you feel lighter and more relaxed?

I think setting aside some time for my hobbies would be a good start. Maybe I could plan a mini creative project or have a dedicated music hour each day to unwind and help shift my focus away from stress.

That sounds like a wonderful plan. Setting aside time for your hobbies and having a dedicated music hour could really help you unwind and shift your focus. It's great to see you're taking these steps towards feeling lighter and more relaxed. Remember, it's okay to take things one step at a time and be gentle with yourself as you transition away from this stress. If you feel like you need more support or adjustments along the way, I'm here to help. Keep nurturing those creative projects and music sessions, and let yourself enjoy the moments. You're doing an amazing job finding what works best for you.
Thanks, that means a lot. I'll try to remember to be gentle with myself as I get started on these changes.

concern:
Not sure if anyone else feels this way but it can be a lonely journey in grad school especially because of the niche stresses, things we have to deal with. 

Created a group me that will hopefully foster some community for people to talk with one another and build some friendships or the very least camaraderie 

Here’s the link to join: You're invited to my new group 'Grad School Community' on GroupMe. Click here to join: https://groupme.com/join_group/86601776/iTupsbUn

dialogue_total.statement: Hi there! I'm glad you came in today. Feel free to share what's on your mind or any concerns you might have.
Hey, thanks. I've just been feeling a bit isolated in grad school. It's hard to connect with others who get the same kind of stresses.
It sounds like grad school has been quite challenging for you. What do you imagine your experience might look like if you felt more connected with others?
If I felt more connected, I'd probably feel less overwhelmed. It would be nice to have people to talk to who really understand what I'm going through.

Feeling connected seems really important to you. Based on what you've mentioned, possible options might include joining a study group or a grad school social club. What steps do you think you could take to start feeling more connected?

client: I've actually started a GroupMe chat for grad students to create a sense of community and camaraderie. I'm hoping it’ll help me and others find some support and maybe even make a few friends who understand the grad school grind.

It's wonderful to hear you've taken a proactive step by starting a GroupMe chat for grad students. That initiative shows real courage and a desire to build a supportive network. By creating this space, you're not only helping yourself but also offering others a chance to connect and share their experiences. As you continue with this, remember that it's okay to reach out and invite people to engage. 

The goals you've set are clear: seeking a sense of community and mutual support. You've already taken a significant action step by initiating the chat, and that's something to be proud of. For coping strategies, consider setting aside regular times to engage with the group or even suggesting in-person meetups when possible. 

As a next step, you might reflect on how the chat is going and think about any additional activities or discussions that could deepen these connections. You’ve got a great foundation, and I’m confident that you'll find the camaraderie you’re seeking. Keep nurturing those connections, and remember, I'm here to support you along the way.
Thanks, I appreciate that. I'm hoping the chat will lead to some good connections, but I'm worried people might not be that interested.

concern:
I graduated college less than a year ago (May 2022); and my undergraduate experience was already screwed up by COVID-19 - I was forced to skip out on a full year before returning to Senior year because the US did not allow international students to take hybrid classes and my university was not offering at least 3 in-person classes for me during the 2020 - 2021 lockdown. So I got to watch all my friends graduate without me; I did qualify for an accelerated Master's Program in Economics and I was accepted but I opted not to pursue it due to COVID-19 and feeling that I did not want to stay in Fordham for both undergraduate and graduate school.  


Anyway, I somehow managed to get a short-term contract at the World Bank since they hired people from around the world, and if I work for the World Bank in a full-time job for about 15 years I am eligible for permanent residency (green card). For all intents and purposes I really want to stay and live and build a life in the US (especially now with geopolitical events in SE Asia). The problem is that I don't have options for employment in the private sector because the H1-b process is absurdly random and difficult; and the World Bank and IMF have outright told me that I can't get a fulltime job without AT LEAST a Master's Degree (it's already brutally difficult for me to get even a short-term contract role, let alone a fulltime job); and even this employment is not guaranteed.  


I'm thinking of getting a Master's Degree in Statistics or Data Science (an MBA or Master's degree in economics isn't very helpful) but I have checked that I did not take enough undergrad courses in Math or Computer Science to qualify (at least in the US). I'm fairly certain that my math skills and coding skills are nowhere near good enough for grad school (I struggled for a 3.60 gpa even before COVID-19)  
I'm honestly totally lost because I'm being forced to prepare for grad school so soon, just after I managed to find something solid career-wise (I'm 23 turning 24). Otherwise I have to go back to the Philippines and I probably won't have an opportunity to immigrate elsewhere anymore.  


Any advice for my circumstances?

dialogue_total.statement: Hi there! I'm glad you're here. What's been on your mind lately?
client: Hey, thanks for having me. Honestly, I've just been really stressed about figuring out my next steps with work and school, especially since everything feels so uncertain right now.
therapist: It sounds like you're dealing with a lot of uncertainty, which can be really challenging. How do you envision your ideal situation at work and school?

client: Ideally, I'd love a clear path to a stable job in the US, like something that leads to a green card eventually, and to feel like I'm progressing in my career. School-wise, just being able to qualify for a grad program that can actually help me would be great.
That sounds like a well-thought-out vision for your future. What aspects of your current situation do you think are helping you move toward that path, and what might be holding you back?

Honestly, getting the short-term contract at the World Bank seems like a helpful step, but the uncertainty of its duration and the need for a Master's degree feels like a big roadblock. Plus, not having taken enough math or computer science courses limits my grad school options, which is really holding me back.

It sounds like you're recognizing some steps that are moving you forward, like your contract at the World Bank, while also identifying significant challenges. On a scale of 0 to 10, how confident do you feel about overcoming these obstacles and moving toward your goals?
client: Hmm, I'd say maybe a 4 or 5? I know there are pathways, but the hurdles seem pretty big and I’m not sure if I have the right tools or time to tackle them.
Therapist: It's understandable to feel that way given the hurdles you mentioned. What do you think could help increase your confidence from a 4 or 5 to maybe a 6 or 7?

client: I think having a clear plan or some guidance on how to strengthen my grad school application would help. Maybe even connecting with people who’ve been through a similar situation could make it feel more manageable.

Therapist: Those sound like insightful ideas that could really support your journey. How do you think connecting with others who've been through similar experiences might impact your perspective or motivation?

Client: I think it might make me feel less alone in all this and give me some real-world advice on what steps to take. Hearing about their journeys could also be a source of motivation and reassurance that it's possible to overcome these challenges.
Therapist: It's great that you're recognizing the value in learning from others' experiences. What specific steps might you take to start building those connections and gathering insights?

Client: I guess one thing I could do is reach out to alumni networks or forums online where people discuss grad school and career paths. Maybe I could also attend some networking events or workshops related to the fields I'm interested in to meet people in person.
Therapist: Those are proactive steps that could really enhance your understanding and motivation. How do you feel these actions align with your overall goals for grad school?

Client: Well, I think they align pretty well because they could help me figure out exactly what I need to improve on or focus on for my applications. Plus, meeting people already in the field could give me a better idea of what to expect and how to succeed.

Therapist: It sounds like you're on a thoughtful path. Based on what you've shared, possible steps could include setting a goal to join one online forum this week and attending at least one networking event this month. What do you think about these options, and do any potential barriers come to mind that we could plan for together?

Client: Yeah, I think those are doable steps. A potential barrier might be juggling these with my current job and dealing with any rejections or setbacks I might face, which can be pretty discouraging.

You've identified some clear and achievable steps for moving forward, like joining an online forum this week and attending a networking event this month. Balancing these with your current job can be challenging, but it's great that you're already considering how to handle potential setbacks. Remember that setbacks are a part of any journey, and it's important to be kind to yourself. Maybe you could set aside a little time each week specifically for these new activities, so they don't feel overwhelming. Reaching out to peers or mentors who've faced similar challenges can also provide support and guidance. You're moving in a positive direction, and with each step, your confidence will grow. Let's focus on maintaining this momentum and address any obstacles as they come. You're doing great, and I'm here to support you every step of the way.
I appreciate the encouragement, but I'm just worried about how to actually fit everything into my schedule without getting overwhelmed. Keeping up the momentum sounds easier said than done.

therapist: Therapist: Those sound like insightful ideas that could really support your journey. How do you think connecting with others who've been through similar experiences might impact your perspective or motivation?

therapist: Therapist: It sounds like you're on a thoughtful path. What do you think about these options, and do any potential barriers come to mind that we could plan for together?

therapist: You've identified some clear and achievable steps for moving forward, like joining an online forum this week and attending a networking event this month. Balancing these with your current job can be challenging, but it's great that you're already considering how to handle potential setbacks. Remember that setbacks are a part of any journey, and it's important to be kind to yourself. Maybe you could set aside a little time each week specifically for these new activities, so they don't feel overwhelming. Reaching out to peers or mentors who've faced similar challenges can also provide support and guidance. You're moving in a positive direction, and with each step, your confidence will grow. Let's focus on maintaining this momentum and address any obstacles as they come. You're doing great, and I'm here to support you every step of the way.
